ol.li: Understand the definition of \R^n, and how to use \R^n to label points.
Use augmented matrices to solve systems of equations.
Vocabulary words: consistent, inconsistent, solution set.

subsection.title: Preliminaries: line, plane, space, etc.
subsection.p: We use \R to denote the set of all real numbers, i.e., the number line. This contains numbers like 0, \frac 32, -\pi, 104, \ldots

statement.p: Let n be a positive whole number. We define \R^n = \text{all ordered $n$-tuples of real numbers }(x_1,x_2,x_3,\ldots,x_n).

subsection.p: In other words, \R^n is just the set of all (ordered) lists of n real numbers. We will draw pictures of \R^n in a moment, but keep in mind that this is the definition. For example, (0, \frac 32, -\pi) is an element of \R^3.

specialcase.title: The number line
specialcase.p: When n=1, we just get \R back: \R^1=\R. Geometrically, this is the number line.

statement.p: For our purposes, a line is a ray that is straight and infinite in both directions.

subsection.p: The number line \R=\R^1 is an example of a line, but a line is not the same as \R^1. We will see later how to use the elements of \R^1 to label the points on a line.

specialcase.title: The plane
specialcase.p: When n=2, we can think of \R^2 as the xy-plane. We can do so because every point on the plane can be represented by an ordered pair of real numebrs, namely, its x- and y-coordinates.
Note that we use the elements of \R^2 to label the points of the plane, but \R^2 is not defined to be the plane.

statement.p: A plane is a flat sheet that is infinite in all directions.

subsection.p: The xy-plane \R^2 is an example of a plane, but a plane is not the same as \R^2. We will see later how to use the elements of \R^2 to label the points on a line.

specialcase.title: 3-Space
specialcase.p: When n=3, we can think of \R^3 as the space we (appear to) live in. We can do so because every point in space can be represented by an ordered triple of real numebrs, namely, its x-, y-, and z-coordinates.
Again, we can use the elements of \R^3 to label points in space, but \R^3 is not defined to be space!

example.title: Color Space
example.p: All colors you can see can be described by three quantities: the amount of red, green, and blue light in that color. (Humans are trichromatic.) So we can also think of \R^3 as the space of all colors.
Again, we can use the elements of \R^3 to label the colors, but \R^3 is not defined to be the set of all visible colors!
In , we could have used \R^4 to label the amount of traffic (x,y,z,w) passing through four streets.

subsection.p: So what is \R^4? or \R^5? or \R^n? These are harder to visualize, so you have to go back to the definition: \R^n is the set of all ordered n-tuples of real numbers (x_1,x_2,x_3,\ldots,x_n).
They are still "geometric" spaces, in the sense that our intuition for \R^2 and \R^3 often extends to \R^n.
We will make definitions and state theorems that apply to any \R^n, but we will only draw pictures for \R^2 and \R^3.

subsection.title: Solving Systems of Equations
subsection.p: During the first half of the course, we will be primarily concerned with understanding the solutions to linear equations.

statement.p: An equation in the unknowns x,y,z,\ldots is called linear if both sides of the equation are a sum of (constant) multiples of x,y,z,\ldots, plus an optional constant.

subsection.p: We will usually move the unknowns to the left side of the equation, and move the constants to the right.

ul.li: A solution to a system of equations is a list of numbers x, y, z, \ldots that make all of the equations true simultaneously.
The solution set of a system of equations is the collection of all solutions.
Solving the system means describing the solution set parametrically.

subsection.p: A solution to a system of equations in n variables is a list of n numbers: it is an element of \R^n. For example, (x,y,z) = (1,-2,3) is a solution to ; this is an element of \R^3.

paragraphs.title: The elimination method
Augmented Matrices and Row Operations

warning.p: The process of doing row operations to a matrix does not change the solution set of the corresponding linear equations!

paragraphs.p: Indeed, the whole point of doing these operations is to solve the equations using the elimination method.

statement.p: Two matrices are called row equivalent if one can be obtained from the other by doing some number of elementary row operations.

paragraphs.p: So the linear equations of row-equivalent matrices have the same solution set.

statement.p: A system of equations is called inconsistent if it has no solutions. It is called consistent otherwise.
